items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the destruction of records as listed per section 7080.302  of the Retention and Destruction of Records under Board Policies.  
	 
Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as including, but not limited to, detailed records relating to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria fund records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period by an agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
SJCC Admission and Records has the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Application for Admission
Summer 2011 R40's
Summer 2012 R40's & AB540's
Fall 2012 & R40's & AB540's
	 
	 
Census Rosters:
	 
					 
Spring 2001
Summer 2001
Fall 2001

items.item_details:
The proposed courses have been reviewed by the appropriate instructional administrator and approved by the All-College Curriculum Committee, acting on behalf of the local Academic Senate.  The rigor of the approval process assures that each new course has substance and integrity in relation to its discipline and that it fills a clear student need not being served by existing course offerings.  The new courses are:
	 
CIT 101:  Storing and Retrieving Big Data
CIT 102:  Computer and Network Security
CIT 103:  Introduction to Machine Learning, Data Mining and Statistical Learning
CIT 104:  Mining Massive Data Sets
WWT 100:  Calculations in Water/Wastewater Technology
WWT 102:  Introduction to Electrical and Instrumentation Processess
WWT 103:  Basic Plant Operations:  Water Treatment
WWT 104:  Basic Plant Operations:  Wastewater Treatment
WWT 105:  Waste Distribution Systems
WWT 106:  Wastewater Collection Systems

items.item_details:
On December 8, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. in the amount of $149,569 to provide construction services or products for Sequoia Heating Hot Water Piping Replacement Project #32307-09 at Evergreen Valley College approved in Resolution Number 011216-2 declaring an emergency pursuant to Public Contract Code for the emergency re-piping of the Sequoia Lecture Hall.  This hot water piping supplies heating to the aforementioned building.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 002 is for:
	 
O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. to perform the weekend work to tie-in the heating hot water system to the Sequoia Lecture Hall building so as not to disrupt classes during weekday sessions.
O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. submitted a written pricing proposal for this change (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                    $149,569.00    
Previously Approved Changes            $  30,100.00
Change Order No. 002                        $    2,028.00
Revised Contract Amount                    $181,697.00
	 
The net change to O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $32,128.00, which equates to 21.40% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 in the amount of $2,028 to O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. for the Sequoia Heating Hot Water Piping Replacement Project #32307-09 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Sequoia Heating Hot Water Piping Replacement #3307-09 – O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. Change Order No. 00
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Sequoia Heating Hot Water Piping Replacement #32307-09 – O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. Change Order No. 002

items.item_details:
This project entails the cooling system upgrade of eight (8) telecom rooms located on the Evergreen Valley College Campus.  System upgrades to be completed include, but not limited to, installation of indoor split system cooling units, outdoor condensing units along with temperature control units.  Contractor must coordinate its work with the overlapping EVC-2016 Network Upgrades Project on Campus, a scheduled power shut-down, as well as ongoing day-to-day operations of an active school site.
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on April 5, 2016 and April 12, 2016.  It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to many contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On April 27, 2016 construction bids were received as follows:
	 
            Company Name                                                                      Total Contract Value              
            Blocka Construction, Inc.                                                       $366,500
            Environmental Systems Inc. of Northern California              $318,000                                 
           
The District received good contractor participation in the bidding process with five (5) contractors attending the mandatory bid walk.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement in the amount of $318,000 to Environmental Systems Inc. of Northern California, for the IT Infrastructure Improvements Network Closet Cooling #32702 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement is to provide design service to support the SJCC Campus Physical Security Project.  Scope of design services include:  1) Design infrastructure and provide recommended routing for power and data to security camera’s, talk-a-phones and wide area emergency broadcast system (WEBS), 2)  Coordination with the Security Consultant (Catalyst), 3) Provide recommended pathways from IDF/BDF’s to each Wireless Access Point (WAP),  4)  Design infrastructure and provide recommended pathways from existing Main Data Frame (MDF) for fiber optic service replacements from the Business Building to auxiliary gym, and the PE Complex. This project designs the infrastructure upgrades to support the campus wide physical security at San Jose City College.
	 
Request for Proposal (RFP) was sent to on-call pool of Mechanical – Electrical – Plumbing (MEP) engineering firms.  The selection committee evaluated the proposals for best value to the District.  The committee selected Salas O’Brien to perform the design service for this project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement (PAA #SJC - 03) in the amount of $223,000.00 to Salas O’Brien, for Design Services, Physical Security (Phase II) Project #31336 at SJCC.

items.item_details: The City of Milpitas and the County of Santa Clara settled a lawsuit involving disputes concerning certain post-dissolution activities of the former Redevelopment Agency of the City of Milpitas. In order to effectuate the portion of the settlement agreement designed for the benefit of taxing entities such as the San Jose Evergreen Community College District, the City of Milpitas is requesting that San Jose Evergreen Community College District’s Board of Trustees accept, by resolution, its conveyance of all beneficial interest in certain real property known as the Milpitas Sports Center by an Assignment of Beneficial Interest from the City to the District. The Assignment will protect the District’s interest in any proceeds in the event the City of Milpitas terminates public use of the Milpitas Sports Center and sells the property.  The Certificate of Acceptance referencing the Resolution will be recorded in the Public Records of Santa Clara County. Staff is recommending Board approval of the resolution to protect the District’s interest as a taxing entity in any potential proceeds from the sale of the real property.
items.item_recommendation: A Recommendation that the Board of Trustees Approve Resolution Number 052416-1 Accepting the Transfer of the Beneficial Interest of the the Milpitas Sports Center to the City of Milpitas.
items.item_text: Resolution Number 05246- Accepting the Transfer of the Beneficial Interest of the Milpitas Sports Center to the City of Milpitas

items.item_details:
The District and Federation of Teachers, AFT 6157 have completed negotiations for 2015-2016. AFT 6157 ratified the tentative agreements on May 20, 2016, for Articles 4, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 16, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, Appendices B, O, Q, R and S, and salary schedules for 10-month, 11-month, adjunct lecture and lab, work experience and non-instructional.  Salary schedules to increase by 3%, adjunct lecture and intersession/summer lecture pro-rata to increase from 65.75% to 66.38%.  For 10-month and 11-month salary schedule to realign column V and IV to provide at least a $2500 difference for an earned doctorate at each step.  Related salary schedules affected on a pro-rata basis.
	 
	 
See attached

items.item_details:
Under the State Chancellor’s authority to represent the Board of Governors in monitoring the use of the Equal Employment Opportunity Fund for the purpose of promoting equal employment opportunities in hiring and promotion at community college districts, the Chancellor’s Office implemented a new fund allocation model  (Education Code, Section 87107 and Board of Governors Standing Order 374.)  
	 
The purpose of implementing a new model is to increase compliance with legal EEO requirements and provide our students with the educational benefits of a diverse workforce.    The model is based on best practices in EEO.  
	 
In order to receive EEO funds, the District’s EEO Advisory Committee, HR Officer, Chancellor, and Governing Board must certify that the district has met 6 of the 9 Multiple Methods by June 1st.  This agenda item will address how the District has met 7 of the 9 Multiple Methods.
	 
See attached

items.item_details:
At the May 10, 2016 Board Meeting, Board members received 4 Board Policies within Chapter 7 (Human Resources) for their first review. BP 7100 (Delegation of Authority); 7120 (Recruitment and Hiring); BP 7160 (Professional Development); and BP 7700 (Whistleblower Protection).  Based upon feedback from Trustees, edits were made to BP 7120 (Recruitment and Hiring) which are highlighted in blue within the attached document.  
	 
BP 7100 (Delegation of Authority) was removed from this document due to requests from Trustees that "delegation of authority" be consistent with the Board's Ends Policies.  Therefore, this policy will be discussed, edited and brought forward to a future Board meeting for 2nd review/approval.  
	 
It is recommended that the Board approve the attached 3 policies.

items.item_details:
San Jose City College has approved the reinstatement of a Classified Senate.  The events and timelines leading up to the adoption of the Classified Senate were as follows:
	 
January 29, 2016, a Classified Senate Workshop was presented at Professional Development Day.  March 30, the Interim Classified Senate Officers met with the CSEA E-Board and Negotiation group to review and outline expectations of the SJCC Classified Senate.  April 8, the Bay Area Representatives for the California Community College Classified Senate made a presentation to SJCC classified staff.  May 4, an information and question and answer session was held on campus for classified staff.  May 11, SJCC classified staff voted 97% in favor to approve the installation of the Classified Senate and the SJCC Classified Senate Constitution.
items.item_text: SJCC Classified Senate Approved
items.item_text_raw: 1. SJCC Classified Senate Approved

items.item_details:
On May 18, 2016, the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (the "District”) successfully sold its fourth and final series of Measure G (2010) bonds in the amount of $58,000,000 (the “Bonds”).
	 
Pursuant to California Education Code Section 15146 (d), actual cost information for the sale must be shared at the next scheduled public meeting.  Following is a financing summary which details the costs of issuance, interest rates and repayment schedule for the Bonds.  The District will receive the bond proceeds on June 9, 2016.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
